Different variable names


The variables involved in differential equations need not be \(x\) and \(y\). Any symbols for variables may be used. Other first order differential equations are \[\dfrac{\mathrm{d}z}{\mathrm{d}t}=te^z,\quad \dfrac{\mathrm{d}\theta}{\mathrm{d}t} =- \theta \quad \text{and} \quad \dfrac{\mathrm{d}v}{\mathrm{d}r}=v\left({\dfrac{1}{r^2}}\right). \] Given a differential equation in the form \[\dfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}=f(x)g(y),\] we can divide through by \(g(y)\) to obtain \[\dfrac{1}{g(y)}\dfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}=f(x). \] If we now integrate both sides of this equation with respect to \(x\) we obtain \[ \int \dfrac{1}{g(y)}\dfrac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}\, \mathrm{d}x=f(x) \,\mathrm{d}x \] that is \[ \int \dfrac{1}{g(y)} \, \mathrm{d}y = f(x)\, \mathrm{d}x. \] We have seperated the variables because the left-hand side contains only the variable \(y\), and the right-hand side contains only the variable \(x\). We can now try to integrate each side separately. If we can actually perform the required integrations we will obtain a relationship between \(y\) and \(x\). Examples of this process are given in the next subsection.

Method of Separation of Variables:

Key Point

The solution of the equation \[ {\mathrm{d}y\over \mathrm{d}x}=f(x)g(y) \] may be found from separating the variables and integrating: \[ \int {1\over g(y)}\,\mathrm{d}y=\int f(x)\,\mathrm{d}x \]
